issues.description: The problem statement's plain-text attribute list (line 17) names two attributes as `inscribedStudents` and `guestStudents`, while the UML diagram (lines 63-68) and the solution implementation (solution_repository/src/de/tum/cit/ase/Lecture.java lines 6-10) use the longer names `numberOfInscribedStudents` and `numberOfGuestStudents`. This naming discrepancy (text vs UML/solution) can confuse students about the exact attribute names they should create and about the expected constructor/getter/setter names, and may lead to mismatches with automated tests that expect the UML-style names.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the attribute naming consistent across the problem statement and UML. Update the plain-text list in the problem statement to use the UML-style names `numberOfInscribedStudents` and `numberOfGuestStudents` (or alternatively change the UML and solution to use `inscribedStudents`/`guestStudents`). Prefer aligning the textual description to the UML/solution so students clearly know the expected attribute names and corresponding getter/setter/constructor parameter names.

issues.description: The problem statement's textual list of attributes uses the names `inscribedStudents` and `guestStudents`, while the UML diagram, example toString, and the solution implementation use `numberOfInscribedStudents` and `numberOfGuestStudents`. This inconsistency (text vs. UML/solution) can confuse students about the exact attribute names and the expected getter/setter names used in tests (which follow the 'numberOf...' naming).
issues.suggested_fix: Make the attribute names consistent across the problem statement and UML/solution. Update the textual list in the problem statement to use `numberOfInscribedStudents` and `numberOfGuestStudents` (to match the UML and solution), or alternatively change the UML and solution to use `inscribedStudents`/`guestStudents` if the shorter names are preferred. Prefer aligning the problem text to the UML/tests to avoid student confusion.
